description: Documents showing different notice periods for employment termination
expected_issues: Notice period varies: Policy Manual states 3 months, Offer Letter states 1 month, Contract states 2 months
Probation period notice differs between documents
Payment in lieu of notice terms are contradictory

documents.title: Company Policy Manual - Termination Procedures
documents.content:
TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT

Notice Requirements:

Management Level Employees: Either party may terminate the employment relationship by providing three (3) months' written notice to the other party. The Company reserves the right to make payment in lieu of notice at its sole discretion.

General Staff: A notice period of one (1) month is required from either party. During the notice period, employees are expected to continue performing their duties diligently and assist with transition activities.

Probationary Period: During the probationary period (first 3 months of employment), either party may terminate employment with 7 days' notice or payment in lieu thereof.

Immediate Termination: The Company reserves the right to terminate employment immediately without notice or payment in lieu of notice in cases of gross misconduct, including but not limited to theft, fraud, violence, or serious breach of company policies.

Garden Leave: The Company may elect to place an employee on garden leave during the notice period, during which the employee will continue to receive full salary and benefits but will not be required to attend work or perform duties.

documents.title: Offer Letter - Manager Position
documents.content:
Dear [Candidate Name],

We are pleased to offer you the position of Marketing Manager at our company.

Start Date: January 15, 2024

Probation Period: Your employment will be subject to a probationary period of 6 months. During this period, either party may terminate the employment with one week's written notice.

Notice Period: Following successful completion of the probation period, either party wishing to terminate employment must provide one (1) month's written notice. The Company may choose to pay one month's salary in lieu of notice.

Severance: In the event of redundancy, you will be entitled to severance pay in accordance with the Employment Ordinance, subject to meeting the eligibility requirements.

This offer is contingent upon satisfactory reference checks and verification of your qualifications.

Please sign and return this letter by December 22, 2023 to confirm your acceptance.

We look forward to welcoming you to our team.

Sincerely,
Human Resources Department

documents.title: Employment Contract - Article 8
documents.content:
ARTICLE 8: TERMINATION

8.1 NOTICE PERIOD
Either party may terminate this Agreement by giving the other party not less than two (2) months' prior written notice in writing, or payment of two months' salary in lieu of notice.

8.2 PROBATIONARY PERIOD
During the probationary period of three (3) months from the Commencement Date, either party may terminate this Agreement by giving not less than one (1) month's written notice or one month's salary in lieu of notice.

8.3 TERMINATION WITHOUT NOTICE
The Employer may terminate this Agreement summarily without notice and without payment in lieu of notice if the Employee:
a) Is guilty of serious misconduct
b) Commits any serious or persistent breach of this Agreement
c) Is convicted of any criminal offence (other than minor traffic violations)
d) Becomes bankrupt or enters into any composition with creditors

8.4 PAYMENT IN LIEU OF NOTICE
The Employer may at its absolute discretion elect to pay the Employee salary in lieu of notice. Such payment shall be calculated based on the Employee's basic monthly salary and shall be made within seven (7) days of termination.

8.5 RETURN OF PROPERTY
Upon termination of employment for whatever reason, the Employee shall immediately return to the Employer all property, documents, and materials belonging to the Employer, including but not limited to keys, access cards, mobile phones, laptops, and confidential information.
